smell_analysis.justification: Every named diagram page (pages 1-18) contains visible model content such as use cases, classes, tables, actions, or states; no diagram consists solely of an empty frame or title.

In the use case diagram 'Treeningu funktsionaalne allsüsteem' on page 2, all use case ovals are drawn inside the system boundary and appear connected by association or include relationships; there is no clearly isolated use case without any connection to an actor, so no unambiguous violation can be identified.

The use cases on page 2 all describe distinct activities (for example, 'Aktiveeri treening', 'Lõpeta treening', 'Unusta treening', 'Vaata kõiki treeninguid', 'Vaata treeningute koondaruannet') and no pair of use cases with the same actor clearly represents the same activity under different names.

In the package/overview diagram on page 1, each package lists its contained elements only once (for example, 'Treening', 'Treening_kategooria_omamine' and 'treeningute elutsüklid' under 'Treeningute register'); no package shows two separate model elements with the same primary name.

In the database-related diagrams (for example pages 10 and 13-18), repeated data such as identifiers and status codes (isik_id, Treeningu_seisundi_liik_kood, kliendi_seisundi_liik_kood) are consistently represented via foreign key relationships between tables; there is no clear case where the same business value is stored redundantly in multiple tables without an FK connector.

Use case names in 'Treeningu funktsionaalne allsüsteem' (page 2) follow a consistent verb-led style in Estonian, such as 'Tuvasta kasutaja', 'Aktiveeri treening', 'Registreeri treening', 'Vaata aktiivseid treeninguid', and 'Unusta treening'; there is no mixture of noun-only and verb-led forms.

In the state diagram 'Treeningu seisundidiagramm' on page 11, each state (Ootel, Aktiivne, Mitteaktiivne, Unustatud, Lõpetatud) is linked by at least one transition from the initial node or another state; no state appears without an incoming transition, so no unreachable state is clearly present.

In the activity diagrams for completing and activating a training (pages 3 and 4), all actions such as 'Vaata kõiki treeninguid, mida saab lõpetada', 'Otsi treeningut', 'Vali treening', 'Lõpeta valitud treening', 'Aktiveeri valitud treening' and 'Kuva veateade Aktiviseerimiseks peab treeningul olema kategooria' lie on paths starting from 'Algus' and leading toward 'Lõpp'; there are no actions drawn without incoming control flow, so no unreachable actions are evident. Question-style labels like 'Kas soovib otsida?' are attached to decision nodes rather than separate actions and are therefore out of scope.

Across all class and database diagrams (for example pages 5-10 and 12-18), relationships either show explicit multiplicity labels at both ends (such as '1' and '0..*' between 'Isik' and related elements on pages 5-7) or are represented as standard foreign key or crow's-foot style connectors in the transformed database diagrams; there are no plain association lines completely lacking multiplicity indications at both ends.

The use case diagram 'Treeningu funktsionaalne allsüsteem' on page 2 contains 11 distinct use cases ('Tuvasta kasutaja', 'Aktiveeri treening', 'Lõpeta treening', 'Registreeri treening', 'Muuda treening', 'Muuda treening mittaktiivseks', 'Vaata aktiivseid treeninguid', 'Vaata kõiki treeninguid', 'Vaata kõiki ootel või mitteaktiivseid treeninguid', 'Vaata treeningute koondaruannet', 'Unusta treening'), exceeding the threshold of 10 central elements (use cases) defined in this rule. Other diagrams contain fewer than 10 classes, tables, or states.

In the class and database diagrams, even the most connected elements (for example 'Isik' in 'Isikute register' on page 6 and 'Treening' in 'Treeningute register' on page 10) have at most a handful of visibly distinct relationship lines; no single class or table can be clearly seen with six or more separate connectors on a single diagram.

Element spacing in the diagrams is reasonably uniform: related elements (such as classes connected by associations or tables connected by foreign keys) are placed at similar distances, and no pair of connected elements is visually separated by a distance clearly more than twice the average distance between elements on the same diagram.

All use case names and activity actions begin with an active verb in Estonian, for example 'Tuvasta kasutaja', 'Aktiveeri treening', 'Vaata kõiki treeninguid', 'Otsi treeningut', 'Vali treening', 'Lõpeta valitud treening' and 'Kuva veateade Aktiviseerimiseks peab treeningul olema kategooria'. Question-style texts like 'Kas soovib otsida?' label decision nodes rather than actions and are not considered use cases or actions under this rule.

No class, table, attribute, or use case name in the diagrams is 3 or fewer characters long; very short labels such as 'Alg' appear only on initial nodes in the state diagram and are pseudostate names, not class/table/attribute/use-case names covered by this rule.

Entity class names such as 'Isik', 'Kasutajakonto', 'Treening', 'Klient' and 'Töötaja' all begin with uppercase letters and are singular. Plural register names like 'Isikute register' and 'Treeningute register' are domain register constructs, which the interpretation rules state should not be checked for pluralization under this rule.

Several attributes/columns start with uppercase letters. For example, in the 'Treeningute register' class diagram on page 10, the attribute 'Maksumus' of 'Treening' begins with uppercase 'M'. In 'Klassifikaatorite register' on page 7, attribute 'Kirjeldus' in 'Töötaja_roll' starts with uppercase 'K'. In the transformed database diagrams, column names such as 'Treeningu_id' and 'Treeningu_asukoha_kood' in 'Treeningute register (transformed)' on page 18 also start with uppercase letters after the key markers, violating the rule that attribute and column names should not begin with an uppercase letter.

Database table names in the transformed diagrams (for example 'Isik', 'Kasutajakonto', 'Klient', 'Tootaja', 'Treening', 'Treening_kategooria_omamine', 'Treeningu_seisundi_liik') are singular or compound descriptors rather than plurals; plural-like phrases apply only to register constructs, which are excluded from this rule.

Class, table, and attribute names do not use type-indicating prefixes or abbreviations such as 'tbl_', 'uc_' or 'strName'. The only prefixes present are key and index markers like 'PK_', 'FK_', 'pfK_' and 'IXFK_', which are explicitly allowed by the rule.
